docs.title: What is This Homelab?
docs.text:
This homelab is a personal Kubernetes cluster that I use to:

  • Learn container orchestration and cloud-native technologies
  • Experiment with different applications and services
  • Self-host useful tools and applications
  • Practice DevOps and infrastructure management skills

docs.title: Infrastructure Overview
docs.text:

  • Kubernetes Cluster: Multi-node K8s cluster for container orchestration
  • Harbor Registry: Private container image registry at 192.168.1.206:30002
  • Persistent Storage: For stateful applications and data persistence
  • Networking: Internal networking and service exposure

docs.title: Harbor, Docker & Kubernetes Deployment Guide
docs.text: This document provides a comprehensive guide for building, pushing to Harbor registry, and deploying the FastAPI application to a Kubernetes cluster.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Docker installed and running
  • Kubernetes cluster access (kubectl configured)
  • Harbor registry running at http://192.168.1.206:30002/
  • Harbor user account with push/pull permissions

docs.title: Application Overview
docs.text:
This is a simple FastAPI application with the following endpoints:

  • GET / - Returns a welcome message
  • GET /items/{item_id} - Returns item information with optional query parameter

docs.title: 1.1 Login to Harbor
docs.text:
First, log in to your Harbor registry using Docker:

docker login 192.168.1.206:30002

You'll be prompted for your Harbor username and password.

docs.title: 1.2 Create a Project in Harbor
docs.text:
1. Open Harbor web interface: http://192.168.1.206:30002/
  2. Login with your credentials
  3. Create a new project (e.g., fastapi-apps or learning-projects)
  4. Make note of the project name - you'll need it for image tagging

docs.title: 2.1 Build the Docker Image
docs.text:
Build the image with proper Harbor registry tagging:

# Replace 'your-project' with your actual Harbor project name
docker build -t 192.168.1.206:30002/your-project/fast-api-docker:latest .

docs.title: 2.2 Tag Image (if needed)
docs.text:
If you built with a different tag initially, retag it:

docker tag fast-api-docker:latest 192.168.1.206:30002/your-project/fast-api-docker:latest

docs.title: 2.3 Push to Harbor Registry
docs.text: docker push 192.168.1.206:30002/your-project/fast-api-docker:latest

docs.title: 2.4 Verify Image in Harbor
docs.text:
1. Go to Harbor web interface
  2. Navigate to your project
  3. Verify the fast-api-docker repository is created
  4. Check that the latest tag is available

docs.title: 3.1 Create Harbor Secret for Kubernetes
docs.text:
Create a secret to allow Kubernetes to pull images from Harbor:

kubectl create secret docker-registry harbor-secret \
  --docker-server=192.168.1.206:30002 \
  --docker-username=<harbor-username> \
  --docker-password=<harbor-password> \
  --namespace=test-namespace

docs.title: 3.2 Update Deployment Configuration
docs.text:
Update the deployment YAML to use your Harbor image. The current configuration should be modified to use Harbor instead of ghcr.io:

Current deployment configuration (fast-api-docker-deployment.yaml):

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: fast-api-docker
  namespace: test-namespace
  labels:
    app: fast-api-docker
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: fast-api-docker
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: fast-api-docker
    spec:
      imagePullSecrets:
      - name: harbor-secret  # Updated secret name
      containers:
      - name: fast-api-docker
        image: 192.168.1.206:30002/your-project/fast-api-docker:latest  # Updated image
        ports:
        - containerPort: 80
        resources:
          requests:
            memory: "64Mi"
            cpu: "50m"
          limits:
            memory: "128Mi"
            cpu: "100m"

docs.title: 3.3 Deploy to Kubernetes
docs.text:
Apply the deployment and service configurations:

# Deploy the application
kubectl apply -f fast-api-docker-deployment.yaml

# Create the service
kubectl apply -f fast-api-docker-service.yaml

docs.title: 3.4 Verify Deployment
docs.text:
Check deployment status:

# Check deployment status
kubectl get deployments -n test-namespace

# Check pods
kubectl get pods -n test-namespace -l app=fast-api-docker

# Check services
kubectl get services -n test-namespace

# Get detailed pod information
kubectl describe deployment fast-api-docker -n test-namespace

docs.title: 3.5 Access the Application
docs.text:
Since the service is configured as NodePort, find the assigned port:

kubectl get service fast-api-docker-service -n test-namespace

Access your application:

  • If running on a cluster node: http://<node-ip>:<nodeport>
  • Test the API endpoints:
  • curl http://<node-ip>:<nodeport>/
  • curl http://<node-ip>:<nodeport>/items/42?q=test

docs.title: 4.1 Making Changes and Redeploying
docs.text:
When you make changes to your application:

  1. Rebuild the image with a new tag:
docker build -t 192.168.1.206:30002/your-project/fast-api-docker:v1.1 .
  1. Push the new version:
docker push 192.168.1.206:30002/your-project/fast-api-docker:v1.1
  1. Update the deployment:
kubectl set image deployment/fast-api-docker fast-api-docker=192.168.1.206:30002/your-project/fast-api-docker:v1.1 -n test-namespace
  1. Check rollout status:
kubectl rollout status deployment/fast-api-docker -n test-namespace

docs.title: 4.2 Rolling Back
docs.text:
If you need to rollback to a previous version:

# View rollout history
kubectl rollout history deployment/fast-api-docker -n test-namespace

# Rollback to previous version
kubectl rollout undo deployment/fast-api-docker -n test-namespace

docs.title: 5.1 Common Issues
docs.text:
Image Pull Errors:

  • Verify Harbor credentials are correct
  • Check if the secret harbor-secret exists in the correct namespace
  • Ensure the image path is correct in the deployment YAML

Pod Not Starting:

  • Check pod logs: kubectl logs <pod-name> -n test-namespace
  • Verify resource requirements are appropriate
  • Check if the container port (80) matches your application

Service Not Accessible:

  • Verify the service selector matches deployment labels
  • Check if the target port matches container port
  • Confirm NodePort service is created properly

docs.title: 5.2 Useful Commands
docs.text:
# View pod logs
kubectl logs -f deployment/fast-api-docker -n test-namespace

# Get into pod shell for debugging
kubectl exec -it <pod-name> -n test-namespace -- /bin/bash

# Port forward for local testing
kubectl port-forward service/fast-api-docker-service 8080:80 -n test-namespace

# Delete deployment (for clean restart)
kubectl delete -f fast-api-docker-deployment.yaml
kubectl delete -f fast-api-docker-service.yaml

docs.title: 6. Harbor Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use specific tags instead of latest for production deployments
  2. Enable vulnerability scanning in Harbor for security
  3. Set up image retention policies to manage storage
  4. Use Harbor projects to organize different applications
  5. Configure Harbor replication for backup and disaster recovery

docs.title: 7. Next Steps
docs.text:
1. Set up CI/CD Pipeline: Automate the build and deployment process
  2. Configure Ingress: Use Ingress controller instead of NodePort for production
  3. Add Monitoring: Implement monitoring with Prometheus and Grafana
  4. Security Hardening: Implement security policies and network policies

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
This workflow demonstrates:

  • Building Docker images for a FastAPI application
  • Pushing images to Harbor registry
  • Deploying to Kubernetes using Deployments and Services
  • Managing application updates and rollbacks

The setup provides a solid foundation for learning container orchestration with Kubernetes and container registry management with Harbor.

docs.title: What is Pre-commit?
docs.text: Pre-commit is a framework for managing and maintaining multi-language pre-commit hooks. It automatically runs a set of checks every time you commit changes, catching issues before they reach the repository.

docs.title: Configuration File: .pre-commit-config.yaml
docs.text:
The repository includes a .pre-commit-config.yaml file that defines which tools to run:

repos:
  # General file quality hooks
  - repo: https://github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit-hooks
    rev: v4.6.0

  4. Ensure image is tagged correctly with full registry path

docs.title: ImagePullBackOff Errors
docs.text:
Problem: Pods stuck in ImagePullBackOff state

Diagnosis:

kubectl describe pod <pod-name> -n <namespace>

Common Solutions:

  1. Missing Pull Secret:
kubectl create secret docker-registry harbor-secret \
  --docker-server=192.168.1.206:30002 \
  --docker-username=<username> \
  --docker-password=<password> \
  --namespace=<namespace>

  1. Wrong Image Path: Verify the image exists in Harbor and path is correct

  2. Network Issues: Check if cluster can reach Harbor registry

docs.title: Persistent Volume Issues
docs.text:
Problem: Pods can't mount persistent volumes

Solutions:

  1. Check if PV and PVC are bound:
kubectl get pv,pvc -n <namespace>
  1. Verify storage class exists:
kubectl get storageclass
  1. Check node permissions for local storage

docs.title: Service Not Accessible
docs.text:
Problem: Can't access services via NodePort or LoadBalancer

Diagnosis:

kubectl get svc -n <namespace>
kubectl describe svc <service-name> -n <namespace>

Solutions:

  1. NodePort Issues:
  2. Check if port is in valid NodePort range (30000-32767)
  3. Verify firewall rules allow the port

  4. Test from within cluster first

  5. LoadBalancer Issues:

  6. Verify LoadBalancer controller is installed

  7. Check external IP assignment

  8. Ingress Issues:

  9. Verify Ingress controller is running
  10. Check DNS resolution
  11. Validate TLS certificates if using HTTPS

docs.title: Pod Evictions
docs.text:
Problem: Pods getting evicted due to resource pressure

Diagnosis:

kubectl top nodes
kubectl top pods --all-namespaces
kubectl describe node <node-name>

Solutions:

  1. Increase resource limits in deployments
  2. Add more worker nodes
  3. Optimize resource requests
  4. Clean up unused images and containers

docs.title: Pod Issues
docs.text:
# Check pod status and events
kubectl get pods -n <namespace>
kubectl describe pod <pod-name> -n <namespace>
kubectl logs <pod-name> -n <namespace>

# Get shell access to pod
kubectl exec -it <pod-name> -n <namespace> -- /bin/bash

docs.title: Service Issues
docs.text:
# Test service connectivity
kubectl port-forward svc/<service-name> <local-port>:<service-port> -n <namespace>

# Check endpoints
kubectl get endpoints <service-name> -n <namespace>

docs.title: Network Debugging
docs.text:
# Run network debug pod
kubectl run tmp-shell --rm -i --tty --image nicolaka/netshoot -- /bin/bash

# DNS testing
nslookup <service-name>.<namespace>.svc.cluster.local

docs.title: When All Else Fails
docs.text:
1. Check cluster events: kubectl get events --sort-by=.metadata.creationTimestamp
  2. Restart problematic pods: kubectl delete pod <pod-name> -n <namespace>
  3. Check cluster logs: Look at kubelet and container runtime logs on nodes
  4. Community help: Search GitHub issues, Stack Overflow, or Kubernetes Slack

docs.title: Prevention Tips
docs.text:
• Always use resource limits and requests
  • Implement health checks (liveness/readiness probes)
  • Monitor resource usage regularly
  • Keep cluster and applications updated
  • Use proper secrets management
  • Document your configurations
